questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause for deviated nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Allergic rhinitis does not cause deviated nasal septum (DNS).

Etiology of DNS:

  • Trauma - during passage through the birth canal or trauma after birth leading to fracture of the nasal septum
  • Developmental error - may be associated with cleft lip, cleft palate
  • Racial factor - more common in Caucasians 
  • Hereditary - affects more than one member of the same family

questions.text: A 3rd-year MBBS student is examining a case of deviated nasal septum. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nasal polyp will not be seen in a patient with deviated nasal septum. 

Clinical features of DNS:

  • Nasal obstruction - unilateral in C-shaped deviation and bilateral in S-shaped deviation
  • Headache - may be due to associated sinusitis or due to spur pressing on the lateral wall of the nose
  • Sinusitis - due to obstruction of ostia and poor ventilation of sinuses
  • Epistaxis - from vessels over spur or due to crusting of the nasal mucosa
  • Anosmia - especially in bilateral nasal obstruction
  • Compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on roomier side
  • Frequent middle ear infections
  • Association with external deformities

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing septoplasty in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Which of the following is not an indication for the surgery?
questions.solution:
Nasal discharge is not an indication for surgery in a patient with deviated nasal septum (DNS).

Indications for surgery in DNS:

  • Symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches
  • Recurrent sinusitis and otitis media
  • Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur
  • Septal deviation causing sleep apnea or hypopnoea syndrome

Other indications for SMR (submucous resection) and septoplasty:

  • As a part of septorhinoplasty for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities
  • As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy (trans-septal trans-sphenoidal approach) or vidian neurectomy (transseptal approach)
  • For the approach to middle meatus or frontal recess in endoscopic sinus surgery when deviated septum obstructs the view and access to these areas
  • To gain access for endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with deviated nasal septum is undergoing submucous resection. What is the key incision is used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Killian’s incision is used in submucosal resection. It is a slightly curvilinear incision, taken 2–3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side of the deviated nasal septum.

Option B: Shobinger incision is used in modified radical neck dissection.

Option C: Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is a septocolumellar incision taken between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella.

Option D: Weber Ferguson incision is used in maxillectomy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student presented with complaints of facial pain, nasal discharge, headache, and nasal bleeding. He has a history of recurrent sinusitis in the past. On anterior rhinoscopy examination, the nasal septum is deviated. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is a case of deviated nasal septum and septoplasty is the treatment of choice.

Both submucous resection and septoplasty can be done for DNS. Septoplasty is a conservative approach and more commonly done nowadays. Septoplasty is also the preferred surgery for DNS in less than 18 yrs, if DNS is bilateral and severe.

Submucous resection Septoplasty
Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of cartilage Conservative procedure
Not done in < 18 yrs Can be done adults and persons < 18 yrs if bilateral and severe
Killian’s incision is used Freer’s incision is used
Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on both sides of the septum Flaps raised on only one side
More complications Less complications
Reoperation is difficult Reoperation is easier

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding septoplasty?

choices.text: It is done in cases of symptomatic nasal obstruction.
Mucoperiosteal flap is raised on both sides.

questions.solution:
Septoplasty is a conservative approach where mucoperichondrial/periosteal flap is generally raised only on one side. As much of the septal framework as possible is retained.

Submucous resection Septoplasty
Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of cartilage Conservative procedure
Not done in < 18 yrs Done children and adults
Killian’s incision is used Freer’s incision is used
Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on both sides of the septum Flaps raised on only one side
More complications Fewer complications
Reoperation is difficult Reoperation is easier

questions.text: A mother brought her 5-year-old child with complaints of pain and swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing after an alleged history of fall while playing. On examination, there is bilateral swelling of the nasal septum which is tender and erythematous. Which of the following is false about the given condition?

choices.text: Can result in hump nose deformity
Accumulation of blood under the perichondrium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with bilateral septal swelling following trauma is suggestive of a septal hematoma and can result in saddle nose deformity, not hump nose deformity.

Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It is caused due to trauma, septal surgery, and bleeding disorders. Clinical features include pain, swelling, and bilateral nasal obstruction (the most common presenting feature), and sometimes, frontal headache.

Complications include septal abscess, depression of dorsum (saddle nose), and permanently thickened septum.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is the best management for this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with swelling in the nose after trauma is suggestive of septal hematoma and it needs immediate surgical drainage.

Treatment of septal hematoma: 

  • Aspiration of small hematomas
  • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
  • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
questions.solution:
Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation.

Causes of septal perforation:

  • Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma, foreign bodies
  • Surface irritants - cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays
  • Infections - syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis, rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis
  • Neoplastic - melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma
  • Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitis

Small anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Large perforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts.

Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps. In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches and bland ointments.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with tertiary syphilis presented with complaints of epistaxis, nasal crusting, and nasal twang on speaking. On examination, nasal septal perforation was noted. What is the most likely site for the perforation?

choices.text: Junction of the bony and cartilaginous septum

questions.solution:
The given patient is having nasal septal perforation due to syphilis. The most common site of involvement in syphilis is the bony nasal septum.

Other chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy can cause perforation in the cartilaginous part. Wegener’s granulomatosis causes perforation of both bony and cartilaginous parts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a rural area presented with foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal crusts, and epistaxis. She was diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. On examination, maggots were seen in the nasal cavity. Which of the following is used in the treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Myiasis (maggots in the nasal cavity) is a complication of atrophic rhinitis. It is treated with chloroform diluted with water.

The maggots are larval forms of flies especially genus Chrysomia. The flies are attracted by the foul-smelling nasal discharge in conditions like atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy, and lay eggs in the nasal cavity. These eggs hatch into larvae within 24 hrs and cause intense irritation, lacrimation, sneezing, and blood-tinged nasal discharge.

Treatment:

  • All visible maggots should be picked up with forceps
  • Instillation of chloroform water and oil kills them
  • Nasal douche with warm saline is used to remove slough, crusts, and dead maggots.

questions.text: Bernoulli’s phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Bernoulli’s phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of nasal polyp formation.

Bernoulli’s principle states that when the velocity of air increases, the lateral pressure will decrease. When air passes through the nasal valve area which is the narrowest region of the nasal cavity, velocity increases. This creates a negative pressure that sucks mucosa of sinuses into the nasal cavity leading to polyp formation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was prescribed aspirin for post-MI prophylaxis. But whenever he takes the medication, he develops difficulty in breathing, sneezing, and lacrimation. He has a known family history of bronchial asthma. Which of the following is related to the his condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Samter’s triad where the patient will have aspirin intolerance, asthma, and ethmoidal polyps.

Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp:

  • Chronic rhinosinusitis especially non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis
  • Asthma
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Kartagener syndrome - This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliary dyskinesis
  • Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia
  • Churg–Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Kartagener’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Azoospermia is not a component of Kartagener's syndrome.

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by the triad of:

  1. Bronchiectasis
  2. Sinusitis
  3. Situs inversus

Kartagener syndrome is one of the etiology for ethmoidal polyps.

Young's syndrome consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

Option A: Neutrophilia with red papular rash is seen in Sweet’s syndrome/acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis.

Option C: Mitral stenosis with ASD forms part of Lutembacher syndrome.

Option D: Nasal polyp, asthma, aspirin hypersensitivity form Samter’s triad.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman came to OPD with complaints of bilateral nasal obstruction, headache, sneezing and nasal discharge. On examination, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are present bilaterally that don't bleed on touch. Which of the following is false about the diagnosis?

choices.text: The site of origin is lateral wall of the nose
FESS is the treatment of choice
The mass can grow posteriorly and occupy the choana

questions.solution:
The given case scenario with multiple bilateral nasal masses in a middle-aged woman is suggestive of ethmoidal polyp and it doesn’t grow posteriorly to occupy choana.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: You are an intern examining a child who presented with nasal obstruction and discharge. On anterior rhinoscopy, there is a single smooth glistening mass in the right nasal cavity which can be moved up and down with a probe and doesn’t bleed on touch. The mass is extending posteriorly and occupying the choana. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Infection and allergy are the main etiological factors
The site of origin is maxillary antrum
FESS is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with findings of a single, unilateral polyp that extends posteriorly to occupy the choana in a child is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp. It can present with hyponasal voice and not hypernasal voice.

 

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A middle-aged man with recurrent diffuse ethmoidal polyps is scheduled for a laser-assisted FESS procedure. Which of the following lasers is ideal in this scenario?
questions.solution:
KTP laser (potassium titanyl phosphate) is the ideal laser for the treatment of nasal polyps.

Option A: Nd-YAG laser due to its greater depth of penetration has a higher risk of complications within the nasal cavity.

Option C: CO2 lasers are primarily used for laryngeal interventions. Its use in nasal sinus surgery is restricted as it causes extensive scarring and it cannot be delivered through a flexible fiber-optical system. 

Option D: The use of argon lasers is limited in sinus surgery due to the high cost of the laser tube and the need for a high current power supply and water flow for cooling.
